translated_title: Grand Popo, Very Pleasant Resort, between the Sea, the Lagoon and Traditions!!
translated_text: The city of Grand Popo is located in Benin near the border with Togo around the international road RNIE1. Due to its position, it stretches over 12 km, on a long but narrow land south of the Mono River and towards the East between the lagoon and the Ocean. It has assets, but its facilities are slowly progressing. This gives it the charm of friendly resorts that do not concrete their coastline, which must be protected from the advances of the ocean. On the East side after Grand Popo, a long sandy beach served by a track, stretches along the sea dotted with small fishing villages that liven up the place when they pull up their net in large groups because it is hard work. On the side of the lagoon, which corresponds to the lake fed by the Mono River, which serves as a border, nature is lush and boat trips are offered with spectacular views of the villages, nature and islands, which dot the lagoon. The lagoon ends its journey towards the East at the mouth called "Les Bouches du Roy". I had the opportunity to make this visit with Beninese friends, it is a real treat! At the start of the coastal road, after the Grand Popo inn in the Apoutagbo district, you must see the Voodoo Festival Square on the edge of the lagoon, which is mainly used for the ceremonies of January 10 each year, for the big event in honor of Voodoo. From time to time, Voudoun ceremonies take place on this square with the representation of divinities, such as Zangbeto the protector of the night, the followers of Sakapta god of the earth, as well as those devoted to H√™viosso god of Thunder. The initiates "the Voudounsi" dance to the sound of percussions. They wear loincloths, necklaces as well as adornments to distinguish themselves from other groups. Some enter into a trance made up with yellow and red earth, under the supervision of assistants to avoid any overflow. In September, I attended the lunar new year of the Guins (G√©) who are present on both sides of the border, notably in An√©ho formerly "Petit Popo" in Togo, the festival of the sacred stone Ep√©-Ekp√© brings together many participants when the sacred stone crosses the border to Agou√© in Grand Popo. Finally, in August, the Grand Popo carnival is a real cultural event that is absolutely not to be missed. Similarly, at Pentecost, the NOVITCHA association, which brings together the Xwla people, who are known for being intrepid boaters, brings together locals and expatriates for a large commemorative celebration. Further on, I visited the Xwala Yehwe Voudoun temple of the followers of Agbo√©vi Agban, king of the marine fetishes of the Xwala (pronounced Plat) of H√©v√©. It is small in size and dressed in white on the walls, with the representation, in effigy of King Agbo√©vi Agban. One can see a sacrificial altar and the large fetish Agbo Allomazegbekpon, which is the intermediary between humans and the gods. Voudoun fetishes of the Xwala people are present in the streets in front of houses to protect them from evil spirits. From the point of view of hotel facilities, there are accommodations of international standard, with all the leisure and service facilities. They overlook the beach directly, such as the Mill√©nium Popo Beach Hotel on the Togo border side, then to the East the Tropicana hotel and the Village Vacances Awale Plage hotel and finally the Auberge de Grand Popo at the start of the lagoon path. I tried the Auberge de Grand Popo, it is correct. The Sahoty residence is located on the edge of the Lagoon (hotel prices per night including tax, depending on the rooms are between 40 and 100 euros) I had a very pleasant stay in Grand Popo with, as a gift, the kindness of the inhabitants and their sense of service. The Xwla people (also called Popo) who have their Royal Palace in H√©v√© on the left bank of the Mono are present and lead the Voodoo festivals. The Guins, dressed in white during the holidays, are very active in the region.
